issue.title: feat(misc/e2e): e2e multinode determinism

labels.name: üêπ golang
labels.description: Pull requests that update Go code

issue.body:
Adds multinode integration testing framework to detect consensus determinism issues.

  ## Features

  - **Pure Go implementation** - Process isolation without Docker dependencies
  - **Dual usage** - Functions as both integration tests and standalone tool (useful for bisecting)
  - **Flexible scenarios** - Extensible testing library with predefined test cases
  - **TestingT interface** - Supports both `testing.T` and CLI execution

  ## Details

  The framework spins up multiple gnoland nodes (validators and non-validators) to verify consensus determinism by
  comparing AppHashes across all nodes at each height.

  While the current scenarios haven't reproduced known non-determinism issues, this provides:
  - A foundation for more complex test scenarios
  - An example implementation for custom integration tools
  - Automated regression testing for consensus determinism

  ## Usage

  ```bash
  # Run as tests
  make test # go test 

  # Run as CLI tool
  make build && ./build/e2e_multinode test

pull_request.title: feat(gnolang): consume gas when we allocate
pull_request.body:
### Summary
This PR implements gas charging for memory allocations in the Gno virtual machine, providing better resource management

‚ö†Ô∏è High Impact Note: This change will significantly affect how we render and execute Gno programs, as memory allocations now consume gas. Operations that previously had predictable gas costs may now require substantially higher gas limits, especially for memory-intensive rendering operations.

### Changes Made

#### Core Implementation
- **Enhanced Allocator Structure**: Added `maxBytesUsed` tracking and `gasMeter` integration to the allocator
- **Gas Charging Logic**: Memory allocations now consume gas at a rate of 1 gas unit per byte allocated
- **Peak Memory Tracking**: Only charge gas when memory usage reaches a new peak, avoiding double-charging for temporary allocations

#### Key Features
- **Economic Memory Management**: Memory usage is now economically constrained through gas fees
- **GC Integration**: Works seamlessly with existing garbage collection mechanisms

#### Technical Details
```go
// New fields added to Allocator
maxBytesUsed int64        // Track peak memory usage
gasMeter     store.GasMeter // Integration with gas system

// Gas charging logic - only charge for new peaks
if alloc.bytes > alloc.maxBytesUsed {
    change := alloc.bytes - alloc.maxBytesUsed
    alloc.gasMeter.ConsumeGas(overflow.Mulp(change, GasCostPerByte), "memory allocation")
    alloc.maxBytesUsed = alloc.bytes
}
```

### Test Updates
Updated integration tests to reflect new gas consumption patterns:
- Basic operations: ~1-2K additional gas
- Package deployment: ~500 additional gas  
- Memory-intensive operations: Significant increases (GC test: 512K ‚Üí 262M gas)


### Breaking Changes
‚ö†Ô∏è **Gas Requirements**: Existing transactions may require higher gas limits due to memory allocation costs.

comment.body:
After MaxAllocBytes is reached, the garbage collector resets Alloc, traverses the AST nodes and their values, and reallocates memory. Any object that cannot be visited during this traversal is excluded from Alloc‚Äîthis is how memory is "freed."

During this process, another round of garbage collection may be triggered if no memory can be freed, as demonstrated in this test case. MaxAllocBytes is reached again at [Line 145](https://github.com/gnolang/gno/pull/4302/files#diff-e21293300ec23fe16d93d7f44167d8e5e15c7d823cf430b4389357c1e267beceL145).

Just before maxBytes is reached, it is always greater than curBytes and less than curBytes+size. Without the fix in lines 147‚Äì151, the garbage collector would continue to run indefinitely.


```
garbage_collector.go:

L147:   if maxBytes < curBytes+size {
                     return true
           }
L151:   alloc.Allocate(size)
```

pull_request.title: fix(gnovm): patch edge condition in garbage collector
pull_request.body:
this should be a ‚Äúshould not happen‚Äù that allocation count exceeded during GC(currently the GC‚Äôs counting  accounts for more than what the runtime allocator counts, and will be corrected after).

however  the current logic isn‚Äôt catching it the "should not happen", the fix correct this logic.

Thanks to @piux2 to identify the issue. üôè

issue.body:
### Description

Error when using gnokey to register a new user on Staging r/gnoland/users/v1 . It says "invalid package path".

### Your environment

* Go version go1.23.6
* OS and CPU architecture: macOS 15.5/M1
* Latest commit 5ad225f51aad97bbfda7a3307611fe3721ea41bc

### Steps to reproduce

Install the latest gnokey and generate a key:
```
git clone https://github.com/gnolang/gno
cd gno
make install
gnokey add testreg222
```
Copy the address. Go to https://faucet.gno.land . Click Staging. Add 20 GNOT (by adding 10 GNOT two times). Try to register the user:
```
gnokey maketx call -pkgpath "gno.land/r/gnoland/users/v1" -func "Register" -args "testreg222" -gas-fee 1000000ugnot -gas-wanted 50000000 -send "1000000ugnot" -broadcast -chainid "staging" -remote "https://rpc.gno.land:443" testreg222
```

### Expected behaviour

Should register the user on Staging.

### Actual behaviour

gnokey prints:
```
--= Error =--
Data: invalid package path
Msg Traces:
    0  /Users/jefft0/temp/invalidpath/gno/tm2/pkg/errors/errors.go:28 - deliver transaction failed: log:
--= /Error =--
```

### Proposed solution

I don't know when this problem started. When I run the gnolang node locally, it works. There may be some "stuck" transaction on the Staging node.

comment.body:
This could be related to a comment in the Gno-Core-Contribs group:
"The current version of master is completely incompatible with 99%, if not all, existing transactions from the staging network. We paused the image upgrades until we caught a breather to go back and fixup the staging txs."
I don't get it, why does this happen in GC?

pull_request.title: feat: Gas cost depending on frame size
pull_request.body:
## PR Description
#### Summary:
This PR introduces a gas cost for increasing the maximum number of frame stack entries during execution. As a result, calling recursive functions will incur a higher gas cost compared to performing the equivalent logic using loops.
#### Key Changes:

Added a new parameter MaxFrames to the Machine struct to track the maximum number of frames encountered during execution.

Updated PushFrameBasic and PushFrameCall to check if the current number of frames exceeds the previous maximum. If it does, we consume gas (currently set to 1 unit, but configurable).

#### Context & Considerations
- Initially, we attempted to account for the size of each frame (values, arguments, blocks, etc.), but this concern is already addressed in #4546

issue.title: `GasUsed` does not affect gas fees taken from the user

labels.name: :package: :mountain:  gno.land
labels.description: Issues or PRs gno.land package related

milestone.title: ‚è≠Ô∏èNext after mainnet beta
milestone.description: Issues and PRs that we'd love to tackle after the gno.land mainnet is launched.

issue.body:
## Description

This issue is meant to bring light to some cumbersome aspects of dealing with user fees in gno.land, which started on a rabbit hole from #3771.

## Issue 1 - actual gas used for a tx doesn't affect fees taken from the user

Our `std.Fee` is very misleading:

```go
type Fee struct {
	GasWanted int64 `json:"gas_wanted" yaml:"gas_wanted"`
	GasFee    Coin  `json:"gas_fee" yaml:"gas_fee"`
}
```

The amount the user puts in the Fee is actually the **total amount of whatever the user is willing to pay for the entire transaction**, not just a single unit of gas.

The effective gas price is the ratio of the maximum gas wanted and the maximum fee (for the entire tx).

There are 2 problems I see with this approach:
* we always subtract the **entire** fee the user set, *regardless of the gas used*, while on the other hand we force the user to find a good ratio that is above the minimum one set by the node / network (ex. if the transaction requires a lot of gas as a limit like 5M, the fee needs to be tuned as well manually in order to fall into the correct ratio range set by the network and validator, in this case 1M ugnot, if the min gas price is 0.2ugnot/gas). **Additionally, two users can end up paying different amounts for a transaction, because they put down different valid fee ratios**.
    * ‚ö†Ô∏è Our mempool implementation doesn't even sort transactions for a block by their gas price! ‚ö†Ô∏è
* the gas fees don't actually go anywhere, they are burned (see `DeductFees`, and trace where the banker sends the funds). This is a separate effort / issue https://github.com/gnolang/gno/blob/2c2c018d5320d85b6180e3790571d0a9004f7e40/tm2/pkg/sdk/auth/ante.go#L325-L328
    * Here's the issue: https://github.com/gnolang/gno/issues/3782

I don't see how the `GasWanted` is not useless for transaction payments, given the user just specifies the maximum amount of gas to bypass a node limit, and the actual source of truth for what the user pays is whatever they put down as the `Fee.Amount`:
https://github.com/gnolang/gno/blob/2c2c018d5320d85b6180e3790571d0a9004f7e40/tm2/pkg/sdk/auth/ante.go#L123-L132

---

## Issue 2 - it's impossible to fetch the minimum price per unit of gas

The gno chain has a set minimum gas price in the form of a ratio, ex. 0.001ugnot/gas. There is a limit which is node controlled (validator), and a limit which is set by the network.

The second issue with utilizing fees and fee ratios the way we do -- is that the client (user) sending the transaction to the gno.land chain **cannot estimate the gas fee ratio** they'd need to put down for their transaction to go through.

For example, a user (client) who wants to send a transaction needs to do a few things:
- estimate the gas limit (wanted) ----> they do this using the `abci.simulate` query. We have this endpoint in all of our gno clients (Go & JS). It is worth noting **that the user needs to set an initial guessed value for the gas limit which is high, so the transaction will even be simulated by the node**
    - In order to simulate a tx, they need to sign it (with the guessed gas wanted), get the appropriate gas wanted back from the endpoint, then proceed to put it into the transaction and **resign it** ([the gas fee is a param that goes into the transaction signature](https://github.com/gnolang/gno/blob/2c2c018d5320d85b6180e3790571d0a9004f7e40/tm2/pkg/std/tx.go#L110-L119)). Imagine a multisig transaction that needs to go through this route.
- they need to **guess, literally guess** the minimum gas fee ratio on the network, either though using an indexer service, or retrying with different values until the transaction is accepted into the mempool. Example error message a user will receive when guessing: `insufficient fees; got: {Gas-Wanted: 100000, Gas-Fee 5ugnot}, fee required: {Gas:1000 Price:1ugnot} as block gas`

These 2 issues affect different types of UX:
- the user UX when sending transactions through wallets like Adena
- the developer UX when programmatically trying to send transactions to the network

---

I'd like to know if we can reach some kind of agreement on user transaction fees that mitigates these issues, given we're not too far from the launch, and they have the biggest impact on user experience.

cc @jaekwon @moul @piux2 @dongwon8247

comment.body:
Hi @zivkovicmilos . I also see that the simulated gas fee does not match the actual deducted fee. I use `gnokey maketx call` with `-simulate only`. It says `estimated gas usage: 11520913, gas fee: 12097ugnot`. Then I query `auth/accounts` for the account balance before and after doing the transaction. It actually deducts 172557900ugnot, unrelated to the simulated amount.
Is it already known that the simulated gas fee and actual deducted fees are off by orders of magnitude? Is there an issue tracking this?

---
Minimal Documentation to introduce Blockchain indexing through `tx-indexer`.
I've as well made made an introduction video with a GraphQL live coding example : https://f.io/PVrt6nKL.

comment.body:
I think you should use something else than balance as an example, since for that you can simply query the chain.

I think a good example is building a search tool.

Example, for social content: indexing blog posts and building a full-text-search feature over posts content on top of that, which is something that would cost a huge amount of gas if done on-chain.
Also search for usernames is a good example.
why use metering only in some cases here and not replace the `builder` type with a metered builder?

pull_request.title: fix: compile regx before use
pull_request.body:
Because Compile() happens dynamically run-time, it can cause concurrent map writes: https://github.com/gnolang/gno/pull/4568

This PR fixes it by making sure the regexes we use at runtime are already compiled during init.

This improves efficiency by not requiring a map lookup each time.

issue.title: feat(commondao): support disabling voting deadline checks on vote & execute

labels.name: :receipt:  package/realm
labels.description: Tag used for new Realms or Packages.

issue.body:
Changes `commondao` package to optionally disable proposal voting deadline checks to allow different use cases.

Previous implementation allowed votes without checking the voting deadline, leaving it to the developer to check, and proposal execution did validate that voting deadline passed.

Changes validates deadline on vote and execute by default and introduce a DAO option to disable the validation.

commits.message: chore(keeper): remove debug print in keeper (#4582) Remove a debug print that appeared in `gnodev` and probably in `gnoland`.

fix(keeper): realm diff iteration, make it deterministic by sorting path (#4580)

Fix the nondeterministic issue that might be introduced by #4281
(storage deposit). The `processStorageDeposit` function iterates over a
map, which can lead to nondeterministic behavior since maps themselves
are nondeterministic. Although not optimal, the fix is to sort the realm
path before iterating.

Co-authored-by: Manfred Touron <94029+moul@users.noreply.github.com>

ci(goreleaser): include tests/stdlibs (#4583)

#4563 added these directories to the dockerfiles, but they also need to
be added to the goreleaser config. this is why the master CI for
goreleaser is failing.

fix(gnovm): fix gc gas consumption  (#4516)

This patch ensures that garbage collection incurs a gas fee by counting
how many times object is visited during the process.

(Note: This is a rough estimation. A more precise calculation will be
implemented later, based on benchmarking.)

commits.message:
fix(cs): death loop when `CreateEmptyBlocks==false` (#4564)

address #4538 

~This PR fixes a death loop that occurred when CreateEmptyBlocks was set
to false. This issue caused a node to enter an infinite loop due to an
impossible condition.~

**UPDATE**
The issue is actually deeper. This PR
https://github.com/gnolang/gno/pull/2838 introduced dynamic gas price
updates in the `EndBlocker` function. As a result, every block now
alters the app `cs.state`, even empty blocks, because the gas price
keeper adjusts the gas price based on block gas usage.

Every block modifies the `AppHash` since the gas price state is updated
in the `EndBlocker`. The `needProofBlock` function always returns true
because `cs.state.AppHash != lastBlockMeta.Header.AppHash` is
consistently true.
This leads to an infinite loop when `CreateEmptyBlocks == false`, as the
node continues to attempt to create proof blocks even when there are no
transactions.

So a better fix is probably to make `EndBlocker` only update the gas
price when there are transactions (when gas `consumption > 0`). cc
@piux2

fix 51cdf97b1b911dbb4f566311aee2487f0e159ed3

@zivkovicmilos can you double check this üôè ?

--- 

I need some help testing to ensure everything functions correctly. cc
@jefft0 @mazzy89 @zivkovicmilos

---------

Co-authored-by: Manfred Touron <94029+moul@users.noreply.github.com>
chore(keeper): remove debug print in keeper (#4582) Remove a debug print that appeared in `gnodev` and probably in `gnoland`.

fix(keeper): realm diff iteration, make it deterministic by sorting path (#4580)

Fix the nondeterministic issue that might be introduced by #4281
(storage deposit). The `processStorageDeposit` function iterates over a
map, which can lead to nondeterministic behavior since maps themselves
are nondeterministic. Although not optimal, the fix is to sort the realm
path before iterating.

Co-authored-by: Manfred Touron <94029+moul@users.noreply.github.com>

ci(goreleaser): include tests/stdlibs (#4583)

#4563 added these directories to the dockerfiles, but they also need to
be added to the goreleaser config. this is why the master CI for
goreleaser is failing.

fix(gnovm): fix gc gas consumption  (#4516)

This patch ensures that garbage collection incurs a gas fee by counting
how many times object is visited during the process.

(Note: This is a rough estimation. A more precise calculation will be
implemented later, based on benchmarking.)

pull_request.title: feat(gnolang): consume gas when we allocate
pull_request.body:
### Summary
This PR implements gas charging for memory allocations in the Gno virtual machine, providing better resource management

‚ö†Ô∏è High Impact Note: This change will significantly affect how we render and execute Gno programs, as memory allocations now consume gas. Operations that previously had predictable gas costs may now require substantially higher gas limits, especially for memory-intensive rendering operations.

### Changes Made

#### Core Implementation
- **Enhanced Allocator Structure**: Added `maxBytesUsed` tracking and `gasMeter` integration to the allocator
- **Gas Charging Logic**: Memory allocations now consume gas at a rate of 1 gas unit per byte allocated
- **Peak Memory Tracking**: Only charge gas when memory usage reaches a new peak, avoiding double-charging for temporary allocations

#### Key Features
- **Economic Memory Management**: Memory usage is now economically constrained through gas fees
- **GC Integration**: Works seamlessly with existing garbage collection mechanisms

#### Technical Details
```go
// New fields added to Allocator
maxBytesUsed int64        // Track peak memory usage
gasMeter     store.GasMeter // Integration with gas system

// Gas charging logic - only charge for new peaks
if alloc.bytes > alloc.maxBytesUsed {
    change := alloc.bytes - alloc.maxBytesUsed
    alloc.gasMeter.ConsumeGas(overflow.Mulp(change, GasCostPerByte), "memory allocation")
    alloc.maxBytesUsed = alloc.bytes
}
```

### Test Updates
Updated integration tests to reflect new gas consumption patterns:
- Basic operations: ~1-2K additional gas
- Package deployment: ~500 additional gas  
- Memory-intensive operations: Significant increases (GC test: 512K ‚Üí 262M gas)


### Breaking Changes
‚ö†Ô∏è **Gas Requirements**: Existing transactions may require higher gas limits due to memory allocation costs.

comment.body:
Not exactly.  
- `bytes` tracks the current total allocated memory.
- `maxBytesUsed` tracks the highest value that `bytes` has reached so far (the peak usage).
- `size` is the amount being allocated in the current operation.

When allocating, if `bytes` exceeds `maxBytesUsed`, the difference (`bytes - maxBytesUsed`) is the *increase* in peak memory usage, and that‚Äôs the value used to charge gas. So, `bytes - maxBytesUsed` equals `size` **only when** the allocation pushes `bytes` to a new peak. Otherwise, it can be less than `size` (if `bytes` was already above `maxBytesUsed`).

Let me know if you‚Äôd like a code comment added to clarify this!

comment.body:
`gnokey add -entropy` prints the mnemonic, and **registers a key in the keystore**.

This tool does not interact with a keystore; it simply prints the mnemonic. This allows you to use non-PRNG-based entropy, for example, with a hardware wallet, or verifying that deterministic entropy is really deterministic. Or use the tool for other chains.
